script: NARRATOR: It is the last morning of Peppa's holiday in Italy.
I'm just going for one last walk.
Going for one last swim, Mr. Pig?
Uh, yes. One last swim before I go home.
Holidays are nice, but they don't last forever, Peppa.
Think of all your friends waiting for you back home.
Yes. I miss my friends, and I miss Goldie the fish.
NARRATOR: Granny and Grandpa Pig are looking after Goldie the fish while Peppa is on holiday.
The postcard hasn't arrived yet, Peppa, but I'm sure it will be here soon.
NARRATOR: Suzy Sheep has come to play with Peppa.
-Not yet, Suzy, but she's coming back today.
Are you sure we need all this stuff, Mummy Pig?
-These are important souvenirs from our holiday.
Yes, I have never felt so relaxed.
Whatever I was doing, Mr. Pig, here is your teddy.
Please, take better care of him.
-NARRATOR: Suzy Sheep cannot wait for Peppa to get back home.
No, Suzy, but she's flying home now.
I hope it's sunny when we get home.
NARRATOR: Peppa's family have arrived home.
What has Grandpa Um, she has filled out a bit, hasn't she?
We've brought you some presents from Italy.
NARRATOR: Peppa and Suzy are best friends.
Here is Mr. Zebra, the postman.
A postcard, all the way from Italy.
Ho-ho! We got here quicker than the postcard!
Look, Goldie! I sent you this postcard from our holiday.
Did you have a nice time on holiday, Peppa?
Yes. Did you have a nice time?
Oh, goody! That means there'll be muddy puddles.
NARRATOR: Peppa and Suzy love jumping up and down in muddy puddles.
Holidays are nice, but coming home to muddy puddles is even better!
NARRATOR: Mummy Pig is fixing a big mirror onto the bathroom wall.
NARRATOR: George thinks there is another little piggy in the bathroom.
MUMMY PIG: It's a mirror, George.
George is looking at himself in the big, shiny mirror.
Come on, George, let's find some more shiny things.
we're looking for shiny things to see ourselves in.
Have a look in a spoon.
DADDY PIG: Now, turn the spoon around.
Now I'm the right way up.
Concave surfaces reflect light waves inversely to their origin and...
NARRATOR: Suzy Sheep has come to play with Peppa.
Look. I can make you go upside-down.
Ah! Let's find some more magic, shiny things in the garden.
-NARRATOR: George has found a muddy puddle.
Ooh! It's shiny enough to see our faces.
NARRATOR: Here are Pedro Pony and Danny Dog.
Did you drop something in that puddle?
No, we're looking at the sky.
But the sky is in the sky.
That's my face. It looks funny.
It's a funny, magic mirror spoon.
Woof-woof! I know where there are some big, funny mirrors.
NARRATOR: The parents have brought the children to the fair.
NARRATOR: The tent is full of big, wobbly mirrors.
Ooh! What's happened to my body?
How does it do that, Daddy?
It's very simple. Illusions of optical differentials by convex and concave surfaces generate patterns of...
I've got a long neck, This mirror looks normal to me.
Daddy, where's your big tummy gone?
NARRATOR: It is Mummy Rabbit with her baby twins, Rosie and Robbie.
I've got customers inside the tent.
Aren't the mirrors amazing, Daddy Pig?
Wow! I can see two of you.
I can see you in the mirror, but there's no mirror.
Silly Daddy, it's Miss Rabbit and Mummy Rabbit.
NARRATOR: Peppa's playgroup are going on a trip to the museum.
Oh, dear. Pedro Pony is not here.
I bet he's still in his pajamas.
NARRATOR: Pedro is asleep in his little bed.
NARRATOR: The bus is still waiting for Pedro Pony.
No, Pedro, we've missed the bus.
Oh, Pedro, you do like sleeping.
NARRATOR: This is Granddad Dog's garage.
Are you sure you wouldn't like any petrol?
No, we haven't gone anywhere yet.
I hope we get to the museum before it closes.
Mr. Rabbit is locking up for the day.
We would like to see the museum, please.
Hmm. We were just closing, but I can give you a quick tour.
This is the King and Queens room.
And, through this door, is the most amazing place of all.
-It's the fantastic world you live in.
Come on, Pedro, or you'll miss the bus.
NARRATOR: Nobody has noticed Madame Gazelle and Pedro are missing.
Oh, have you missed the bus?
Mr. Rabbit, I am a teacher.
NARRATOR: Madame Gazelle and Pedro have arrived back at the playgroup.
Yes, Pedro, for once, you are early!
NARRATOR: It is a lovely, sunny day.
Peppa and George are in the garden.
But there's lots to do in the garden.
Sit in a garden chair, read the paper and watch the grass grow.
But those are things for a daddy to do.
Me, too. That's why I came to your house.
We've an old box of garden games somewhere.
We set the skittles up here.
Then we have to stand over here and try and knock the skittles over by rolling this heavy ball.
NARRATOR: Peppa has knocked over two skittles.
You probably won't be able to do it.
NARRATOR: Suzy has knocked over all the skittles.
Because George is little, he can stand a bit closer.
George is too little to play skittles.
NARRATOR: George doesn't like being the littlest one.
Hmm. Let's play bat and ball.
Peppa can throw the ball, and George has to bat it.
But if anyone catches the ball, George is out.
George is a bit too little even for bat and ball.
You just need a bit more practice, George.
Oops. I'll just get the ball back.
Uh, can we have our ball back, please?
Yes, but please play more carefully in future.
My daddy is very good at it.
He batted the ball all the way into the house.
Wow! Can I play bat and ball, too?
Er, maybe it's time for a different garden game.
I know. You jump over it.
It's much too high to jump over.
We go under the limbo pole, and we need music to do it.
NARRATOR: Daddy Pig is very good at limbo.
Ah, but now we'll put the pole a bit lower.
My tummy is not too big.
I just can't bend like I used to.
Now we'll put the pole even lower.
- George is the best at limbo dancing, -because he is little.
NARRATOR: George likes playing garden games.
NARRATOR: Peppa and her family are watching television.
TV ANNOUNCER: And now a special message from the Queen.
Today I have decided to give an award to the hardest working person in the country.
I wonder who that will be?
It certainly won't be you, darling.
The hardest working person in the country is, Miss Rabbit.
NARRATOR: Miss Rabbit runs the ice cream stall, the recycling center, the library.
She drives the train, the fire engine, flies a rescue helicopter, and works the supermarket checkout.
Ahhh! What are you lot doing here?
Miss Rabbit, I have a very special letter for you.
Miss Rabbit, please come to my palace to get a medal for all your hard work.
Relax. No one will be working that day.
The Queen has made it a holiday.
-NARRATOR: It is the day Miss Rabbit visits the Queen.
Peppa and her friends are going too.
NARRATOR: This is the Queen's palace.
Look at all that fancy stuff.
Lots of room for a queen to kick a ball about.
Hello. Have you seen the Queen today?
She's an old lady with a crown on her head.
NARRATOR: Miss Rabbit has fainted again.
I don't wear it much because it's very heavy.
Are you the boss of all the world?
Do you tell people what to do?
The children are very excited to meet you, Your Majesty.
I'm excited to meet all of you.
And now for Miss Rabbit's medal.
This is the Queen's Award for Industry.
You've got a lovely big garden, Your Majesty.
Do you play in it all the time?
I don't have much time for playing, no.
Never mind, we can walk around it.
You can't walk around a muddle puddle.
No. You have to jump in it!
Oh, I say! That does look fun.
If you jump in muddy puddles, you must wear your boots!
NARRATOR: Oh, dear. The Queen is not wearing her boots.
NARRATOR: The Queen loves jumping up and down in muddy puddles.
Everyone loves jumping up and down in muddy puddles!
NARRATOR: Peppa and George are at Danny Dog's house.
Captain Dog is telling stories of when he was a sailor.
I sailed all around the world.
But now I'm back for good.
I'll never get on a boat again.
Daddy, do you miss the sea?
It is Grandad Dog, Grandpa Pig and Grampy Rabbit.
But, Daddy, you said you'd never get on a boat again.
Off. On a boat. Without me.
What are you going to do now, Daddy?
You don't get seaweeds on houses.
Are you sure your boat's safe, Grampy Rabbit?
It's very good of you to steer the boat, Grampy Rabbit.
But I'm not steering the boat.
I've been in worse situations than this.
But we're stuck on a desert island.
With just the sea and the sky for company.
And we haven't got any food.
Ooh, I've got a chocolate bar.
Good. We should save the chocolate in case we get hungry later.
What a terrible place to be stuck.
We've only been here five minutes, Grampy Rabbit.
I'm going to put a mark in the sand for every time I think about cheese.
We need to call for help.
NARRATOR: Grampy Rabbit is very good at shouting.
We can use Grandad Dog's boat.
Wait a minute. I said I'd never get on a boat again.
You're right. Just this once I shall sail again.
There must be something to eat.
NARRATOR: Captain Dog has rescued the grandads.
Thinking of sailing around the world again.
But, Daddy, you're not a sailor any more.
Leave the sailing to us, Captain Dog.
Yes, and when they get lost again you can rescue them.
NARRATOR: Peppa and George are visiting Granny and Grandpa's house.
Peppa is watching Granny Pig at her dressing table.
That's because perfume is made of flowers.
Hm. Granny, I've got a very good idea.
Now I'm going to put flowers in it and make perfume.
That's nice, dear, but only pick flowers from the grass -not from the flowerbed.
Hello, flowers. Who wants to be in my perfume?
I'm going to put you in my beaker of water.
It's going to be the prettiest, smelliest perfume ever.
First, I pick a smelly flower.
Then I put it in my beaker.
It needs to smell of flowers.
NARRATOR: George does not like smelly flowers.
Grandpa Pig is in his herb garden.
I made it with flowers from the garden.
It's the most beautiful perfume in the world.
You can make perfume out of something else.
I have got lots of lovely smelly things in my herb garden.
I like to use it in my cooking.
that smells like Granny Pig's perfume.
That's a strong smell of lavender.
Has George made some perfume too?
No, Granny. He doesn't like the smell of anything.
There must be something you like the smell of.
NARRATOR: George has found a muddy puddle.
-What did you put in it, George?
George's perfume is made out of muddy puddle.
you smell even nicer than you did before.
Yes. You should use perfume de muddy puddle more often.
NARRATOR: Peppa and her friends are at play group.
Mr. Bull is checking the school roof.
Who put this roof on for you?
Lovely job. It will last you a lifetime.
Look, it is going drippety drip.
Where are we going to get the money for a new school roof?
Woof! We can do a school fete to get the money.
Yes! The children can do it.
NARRATOR: It is the day of the children's fete.
NARRATOR: Danny Dog is in charge of the microphone.
Get your money out for the new school roof.
Emily Elephant is in charge of the brick-a-brack stall.
Roll up, roll up, all sorts of bits and bobs.
What a lot of brick-a-brack, Emily.
You will be busy all day selling it.
Mmm. This all looks very interesting.
Would you like a balloon, Madame Gazelle?
May I have a red one?
Oh, of course, we are raising money for the school roof.
Look, Madame Gazelle, I've got rid of everything.
How much money have you raised?
Money? Did you not get some money for the bits and bobs?
NARRATOR: Suzy Sheep is in charge of the face painting stall.
Hello, Suzy. Can I be a mountain leopard, please?
No. I can only do fruit.
NARRATOR: Peppa is in charge of the lucky dip.
Roll up, roll up for your lucky dip.
Ooh. Would you like to try the lucky dip?
Just pull a prize out of the barrel.
NARRATOR: Mr. Bull has won a dolly.
-NARRATOR: Mrs. Cat has won a digger.
NARRATOR: Mr. Bull and Mrs. Cat like their lucky dip prizes.
NARRATOR: Freddy Fox is in charge of the Mummies and Daddies race.
You have to get in the bag and jump over there.
And my mummy is the winner.
But really, we must thank the children for all their hard work.
And we have raised enough money to buy a new school roof again.
NARRATOR: Suzy Sheep has come to play at Peppa's house.
I've got something to show you.
Who do you think it is?
It's an old photo, when I was a baby.
In the olden days, you were a baby, too, Peppa.
NARRATOR: Mummy Pig is working on the computer.
She said, in the olden days, Well, you were, Peppa.
Look, here are some photos on the computer.
NARRATOR: Baby Alexander is Peppa's cousin.
No. That's you as a baby, Peppa.
Somebody sounds like they're having fun!
Look, Daddy. That's a picture of me as a baby.
It was taken on our first day in this house.
When you were little, we moved into this house.
We brought all our things on top of our car.
Mummy Pig put some pictures up.
MUMMY PIG: Daddy Pig put up a shelf.
And Grandpa Pig made us a lovely flower garden.
Where's Grandpa's lovely flower garden now?
Uh, we had the wrong kind of soil for flowers.
You and Suzy loved to play in the garden.
- Yes. You and Suzy have always been best friends.
In the olden days, did Suzy and me jump up and down in muddy puddles?
MUMMY PIG: Soon after that, you were toddlers.
MUMMY PIG: He was a baby, in my tummy.
-Yes, you were in my tummy, George.
You've got a big tummy, Daddy.
Is there a baby in there?
MUMMY PIG: And so George was born.
And Granny and Grandpa gave George a very special present.
Can you guess what it was?
DADDY PIG: And you and Suzy were running and jumping around.
MUMMY PIG: Then, one day you saw something amazing.
Peppa, if you jump in muddy puddles, you must wear your boots.
You loved jumping up and down in muddy puddles.
NARRATOR: Peppa loves jumping up and down in muddy puddles.
Peppa has always loved jumping up and down in muddy puddles.
NARRATOR: It is a lovely, snowy day.

- See you all at the top.

You have to take the ski lift.

Uh, it looks a bit high.

-NARRATOR: Madame Gazelle is the ski teacher.

I think, for now, we will stick to the baby slope.

To start, push off slowly with your sticks.
To stop, point your skis together.
Let's go back up and do it again.

Uh-oh. To go up the slope, you have to walk sideways, like a crab.

Yes. I was the world champion at skiing and won this cup.
Now, which mummy or daddy would like a go?
It's just like riding a bike, Daddy Pig.
Here is the baby slope, Mummy Pig.
All the way down the mountain!
My mummy is skiing down the mountain.

Everyone is in the coach, chasing after Mummy Pig.
Wow! My mummy is skiing super-fast!
NARRATOR: Mummy Pig is skiing past the shops.
I have never seen such amazing skiing.
My mummy is the best at skiing down the mountain.
NARRATOR: Peppa and her family have come to the lake to go boating.
Hmm. You have to paddle a canoe.
It's a bit tricky to sail a sailing boat.
Yes, they've got a big paddle wheel to make them go.
When I ring this bell it's time to bring the boat back.
No. How do we start the engine?
Oh, I see. Off we go, then.

NARRATOR: The Elephant family like canoeing.

Certainly. I have canoes, sailing boats or pedalos.

Do I know how to work it?
-MUMMY PIG: We could go there for our picnic.
The island is a bit small to have a picnic on.
We can have our picnic in the boat.
Come in, boats One, Two and Three!
Let's see who can get back first.

Ah-ha! We'll be carried back by the wind, Danny.

We'll just have to wait for the wind to pick up again.

Yes. Sailing boats have engines on them.
But you said you were going to stay home.

- Oh, dear! Now we'll have to wait even longer!
Why don't you join us, Mummy Pig?

Because china can break very easily.
I put it down too hard!
I don't know my own strength!
Maybe we can fix it, boss.
It's not going to work, lads.

This is Miss Rabbit's china shop.
Yes, but I think I can fix it.
Oh! These two pieces fit together.

There's just this funny-shaped bit left.

And it's right outside Miss Rabbit's shop.
-Can we have a hole outside Miss Rabbit's shop?

Mr. Bull likes digging up the road.
Everybody likes digging up the road!

Welcome to Fruit Day, where the magic of fruit never ends.
We are choosing our favorite fruit.

OK, but smoothies can have lots of different fruit in them.
OK. Apples, raspberries, bananas, and more apples!
An apple, raspberry, banana and more apples smoothie!

OK. Raspberries and blueberries and blackberries and gooseberries.
Raspberry, blueberry, blackberry and gooseberry smoothies for everyone!

Oh, yes. All dinosaurs like dinosaur juice.

-Can I have some dinosaur juice, please, Miss Rabbit?
-I've forgotten what I put in the dinosaur juice.
I can tell you what was in it.

One peach, half a pineapple, a slice of melon...
Are you all enjoying Fruit Day?

NARRATOR: It is Miss Rabbit's ice cream stall.
Oh! I don't think they have dinosaur ice cream.

Do you not want an ice cream, George?
How much is the little balloon?

NARRATOR: George loves his dinosaur balloon.
Peppa and George have arrived back at Granny and Grandpa Pig's house.
there are two sorts of balloons, the up balloon and the down balloon.
it will go up and up and up, all the way to the moon!

Your balloon will be safe in here.
George has got a new balloon.
GRANNY PIG: Don't you pop it, Polly!
It won't fly away, because the roof is in the way.
Oh! It's gone through the door!

George, your balloon is going to the moon.

Have you had a lovely time?
Um, we bought George a dinosaur balloon...

There must be some way we can get it back.

George, don't let go of your balloon again.

Does the aquarium have every type of fish?

Well, I hope you find one.

Oh. We haven't found a friend for Goldie.

Peppa, George, Daddy and Grandpa are inside, watching racing cars on television.

I'm so glad I didn't miss the finish.

I'll make a racing car for George.

-Don't make it go too fast, George is only little.

- Oh, how do we get over there?

-You can't have a picnic without a picnic.

-Here's some cake for you, Mrs. Duck.

-We can melt it to get pretend water.
